instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/robots.txt
Evidence: (none)
Observed: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:47:57 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 555
Connection: keep-alive

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:

Evidence: x-frame-options
Observed: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:47:56 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 4958

Evidence: submit
Observed: User-controlled HTML attribute values were found. Try injecting special characters to see if XSS might be possible. The page at the following URL:

http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php

appears to include user input in:
a(n) [input] tag [value] attribute

The user input found was:
submit=add message

The user-controlled value was:
add messageResponse Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:00 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

content-length: 5393

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/Details/color-printer/3/
Evidence: (none)
Observed: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Alert: Absence of Anti-CSRF Tokens on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=1
Evidence: <form action="search.php?test=query" method="post">
Observed: No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token, _csrfToken] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "goButton" "searchFor" ].Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6428

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2
Evidence: x-frame-options
Observed: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6368

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=1
Evidence: nginx/1.19.0
Observed: The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6428

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Charset Mismatch (Header Versus Meta Content-Type Charset) on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2
Evidence: (none)
Observed: There was a charset mismatch between the HTTP Header and the META content-type encoding declarations: [UTF-8] and [iso-8859-2] do not match.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6368

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2
Evidence: (none)
Observed: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6368

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=1
Evidence: x-content-type-options
Observed: This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.
At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:01 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6428

Evidence: <form action="search.php?test=query" method="post">
Observed: No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token, _csrfToken] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 2: "goButton" "searchFor" ].Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:02 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6453

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:

Evidence: nginx/1.19.0

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

content-length: 6453

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=4
Evidence: x-content-type-options

At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive

content-length: 6453

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=5
Evidence: (none)
Observed: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:48:02 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
content-length: 6382

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input:
Alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/cart.php
Evidence: (none)
Observed: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

content-length: 4903

instruction: Classify and explain if the alert is false positive.
input: Alert: Cross Site Scripting (Reflected) on http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php Evidence: Observed: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is an attack technique that involves echoing attacker-supplied code into a user's browser instance. A browser instance can be a standard web browser client, or a browser object embedded in a software product such as the browser within WinAmp, an RSS reader, or an email client. The code itself is usually written in HTML/JavaScript, but may also extend to VBScript, ActiveX, Java, Flash, or any other browser-supported technology. When an attacker gets a user's browser to execute his/her code, the code will run within the security context (or zone) of the hosting web site. With this level of privilege, the code has the ability to read, modify and transmit any sensitive data accessible by the browser. A Cross-site Scripted user could have his/her account hijacked (cookie theft), their browser redirected to another location, or possibly shown fraudulent content delivered by the web site they are visiting. Cross-site Scripting attacks essentially compromise the trust relationship between a user and the web site. Applications utilizing browser object instances which load content from the file system may execute code under the local machine zone allowing for system compromise. There are three types of Cross-site Scripting attacks: non-persistent, persistent and DOM-based. Non-persistent attacks and DOM-based attacks require a user to either visit a specially crafted link laced with malicious code, or visit a malicious web page containing a web form, which when posted to the vulnerable site, will mount the attack. Using a malicious form will oftentimes take place when the vulnerable resource only accepts HTTP POST requests. In such a case, the form can be submitted automatically, without the victim's knowledge (e.g. by using JavaScript). Upon clicking on the malicious link or submitting the malicious form, the XSS payload will get echoed back and will get interpreted by the user's browser and execute. Another technique to send almost arbitrary requests (GET and POST) is by using an embedded client, such as Adobe Flash. Persistent attacks occur when the malicious code is submitted to a web site where it's stored for a period of time. Examples of an attacker's favorite targets often include message board posts, web mail messages, and web chat software. The unsuspecting user is not required to interact with any additional site/link (e.g. an attacker site or a malicious link sent via email), just simply view the web page containing the code.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.19.0 Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:51:22 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: keep-alive X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1 content-length: 5433

Using a malicious form will oftentimes take place when the vulnerable resource only accepts HTTP POST requests. In such a case, the form can be submitted automatically, without the victim's knowledge (e.g. by using JavaScript). Upon clicking on the malicious link or submitting the malicious form, the XSS payload will get echoed back and will get interpreted by the user's browser and execute. Another technique to send almost arbitrary requests (GET and POST) is by using an embedded client, such as Adobe Flash. Persistent attacks occur when the malicious code is submitted to a web site where it's stored for a period of time. Examples of an attacker's favorite targets often include message board posts, web mail messages, and web chat software. The unsuspecting user is not required to interact with any additional site/link (e.g. an attacker site or a malicious link sent via email), just simply view the web page containing the code.Response Header: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.19.0 Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2025 02:51:29 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Connection: keep-alive X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1 content-length: 765

Evidence: GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php?name=ZAP&submit=add%20message&text= HTTP/1.1
Observed: A request that was originally observed as a POST was also accepted as a GET.
